Award.AbstractNarration:
Faculty beginning their independent careers often find the process of writing their first grant proposals to be challenging. Professors Dominik Konkolewicz of Miami University, Ohio, and Paula Diaconescu of the University of California, Los Angeles are organizing a workshop that seeks to provide new chemistry faculty insight into the proposal writing and reviewing process so that they can identify and develop strong research, education and outreach activities. Participants have the opportunity to network with each other as well as successful grant recipients and federal program officers from a variety of agencies. The participants engage in mock panels, research presentations, and other activities designed to provide them with a better understanding of how to put together a research plan that is ambitious, yet realistic and compelling. Broader impact criteria are also discussed in terms of educational activities, outreach, and technical applications to societal problems.

The 2019 Chemistry Early Career Workshop, supported by the Division of Chemistry will be held on May 20-21, 2019 in Alexandria, Virginia. This workshop will bring together 80 junior faculty from a broad range of institutions and demographics to discuss steps in strategically crafting research ideas, planning educational and outreach activities, and assessing and evaluating project aims. Potential participants can access more information (as it becomes available) at: https://blogs.miamioh.edu/early-career-investigator-workshop/. In addition an email address is also available: che.early.career.workshop.19@gmail.com.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the 2019 NSF CHE Early Career Investigator workshop was to provide early career chemists with networking opportunities and relevant information needed to assess their research ideas, projects, and plans critically in order to compete effectively for funding to the NSF CAREER program, other NSF programs, and other federal agencies.        

            A two day workshop was organized by the PIs in collaboration with NSF staff, and held at the Embassy Suites in Alexandria VA on 19-21 May 2019. Eighty five early career researchers attended the workshop. A comprehensive schedule was developed to allow participants to learn about NSF and other federal agencies, understand the NSF merit review process, engage in interactive ?mock? review sessions, and receive critical feedback on their own proposals and project ideas from NSF program directors and invited mentors. In addition to these activities, networking opportunities were given for the participants to engage with NSF program directors, mentors, and other early career faculty. The intellectual merit of the project was dissemination of information on competitive proposal writing and research group organization, with the opportunity for early career chemists to receive personalized feedback on their groups projects.

            Although the NSF Chemistry Division was the principal partner involved in the planning and development of the project, the Division of Materials Research (DMR), Chemical Bioengineering, Energy and Transport Systems (CBET), Department of Energy Basic Energy Sciences (DOE-BES), Army Research Office (ARO), Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR), National Institutes of Health (NIH) also served as partners. In addition, 11 invited mentors assisted with the project.

            The broader impact of the project was the contribution to training of a diverse and effective STEM ready workforce, especially in the field of chemistry. The mentorship of early career faculty is critical to the development of a strong pipeline of successful chemists and scientists. By mentoring and providing individualized and specific feedback on how early career faculty can obtain funding to support their research, a strong pipeline of faculty and leaders in chemistry is developed. Specifically, the grant enabled 85 participants (out of 124 total applicants) to attend the workshop and gain valuable experience and skills to assist them in becoming successful independent researchers. Of the 85 participants, 28 were female, 2 were African American or Black, and 4 were Hispanic. A range of institutions were served by the workshop including 18 participants from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), 2 participants from historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), and 6 from Hispanic serving institutions (HSIs).

            Based on feedback and the surveys developed after the workshop, most participants found the workshop helpful and an important tool for their career development. In addition, it is anticipated that the experience provided by this grant will allow future organizers to improve upcoming workshops.
